name: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home
description: Secondhand smoke, especially indoors, is bad for health - especially for the health of children.

name: Adults without a Smoke-Free Home Policy
description: A smoke-free home policy can limit people's exposure to secondhand smoke, which is especially dangerous to children.

name: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Work
Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home from Outside Sources
Pre-1960 Homes with Peeling Paint
description: Older housing and peeling paint can put residents at risk of lead poisoning, due to lead paint - which was banned from household paints in the USA in 1978.

name: Children under 5 years old in Poverty
description: Poverty is a major determinant of health, since poverty deprives people of access to health and safety resources.

name: Adults Reporting Rats or Mice outside Their Building
description: Mice and rats outside a building can indicate the presence of mice and rats in people's homes - which can trigger asthma and indicate other health-threatening maintenance deficiencies.

name: Homes with Mice or Rats in the Building
description: The presence of mice or rats in the home is often associated with poor housing maintenance. These pests can contaminate food and contribute to the development and exacerbation of asthma and its symptoms.

name: Adults Reporting Mice in the Home
description: Mice or rats in the home are a source of household allergens connected to the developement of asthma and exacerbation of asthma symptoms. They may also indicate other health-threatening maintenance deficiencies.

name: Children living in homes with mice (ages 0-13  years)
Adults Reporting Cockroaches in the Home
Homes with Cockroaches
description: The saliva, feces, and shedding body parts of cockroaches are an allergen and can trigger asthma.

name: Children living in homes with cockroaches (ages 0-13 years)
Adults Reporting Personal Use of Pesticides
NYC Agency Use of "Best Practice" Products
description: NYC enacted a local law in 2005 that requires city agencies to reduce use of toxic products to control pests, and to adopt “Best Practices” instead. Best practice products use active ingredients with very low toxicity or involve formulation or application methods that minimize potential exposure and environmental spread.

name: NYC Agency Use of Mosquito Control
Adults with Asthma in the Past 12 Months
description: Asthma is a common disease characterized by breathing difficulty. Environmental exposures resulting from poor air quality and housing maintenance are known to increase risk of asthma development and trigger asthma symptoms. Beginning in 2017, indicator includes data imputed for missing responses.

name: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 0 to 4 Yrs Old)
description: Asthma hospitalizations are more severe asthma outcomes. They're often clustered in high-poverty neighborhoods, where disinvestment and poor housing conditions expose residents to triggers.

name: Asthma Emergency Department Visits (Children 0 to 4 Yrs Old)
Public School Children (5-14 Yrs Old) with Asthma
description: Asthma is a common disease characterized by breathing difficulty. Environmental exposures resulting from poor air quality and housing maintenance are known to increase risk of asthma development and trigger asthma symptoms.

name: Public School Children (5-14 Yrs Old) with Persistent Asthma

Asthma Emergency Department Visits (Children 5 to 17 Yrs Old)
description: Severe asthma attacks can result in a visit to the ED. Certain exposures can trigger asthma symptoms, including smoke, air pollution, dust mites, cockroaches, mold, pollen and pet dander, among others.

name: Asthma Emergency Department Visits (Adults)
description: Severe asthma attacks can result in a visit to the ED. Certain exposures can trigger asthma symptoms, including smoke, air pollution, dust mites, cockroaches, mold, pollen and pet dander, among others.

name: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 17 Yrs Old)
description: Asthma hospitalizations are more severe asthma outcomes. They're often clustered in high-poverty neighborhoods, where disinvestment and poor housing conditions expose residents to triggers.

name: Asthma Hospitalizations (Adults)
description: Asthma hospitalizations are more severe asthma outcomes. They're often clustered in high-poverty neighborhoods, where disinvestment and poor housing conditions expose residents to triggers.

Heart Attack Hospitalizations
description: Heart attacks can stem from genetic, lifestyle, and environmental factors including ambient air pollution and second-hand smoke.

name: Children under 6 years with elevated blood lead levels (BLL)
description: There is no safe level of lead in the blood. Lead poisoning can cause learning and behavior problems, and delay growth and mental development.

name: Children tested for lead by age 3 years
Children under 6 years with elevated blood lead levels by NTA
description: Children under 6 years of age with blood lead levels (BLL) at or above 5 mcg/dL, by neighborhood tabulation area (NTA). Read more about neighborhood tabulation areas.

name: Carbon Monoxide Emergency Department Visits
description: Carbon monoxide exposure can be life-threatening or fatal. Maintaining surveillance of ED visits and hospitalizations allows us to understand the burden of CO-related health impacts in NYC and identify trends over time.

name: Carbon Monoxide Hospitalizations
description: Carbon monoxide exposure can be life-threatening or fatal. Maintaining surveillance of ED visits and hospitalizations allows us to understand the burden of CO-related health impacts in NYC and identify trends over time.

description: Occupied housing units with more than one person per room are considered crowded.

name: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home
description: Secondhand smoke, especially indoors, is bad for health - especially for the health of children.

name: Homes with Cracks or Holes
description: Cracks or holes are a maintenance deficiency linked to the presence of mice, rats, and cockroaches - which can harm residents' health.

name: Pre-1960 Homes with Peeling Paint
description: Older housing and peeling paint can put residents at risk of lead poisoning, due to lead paint - which was banned from household paints in the USA in 1978.

name: Homes with Leaks
description: Leaks are a maintenance deficiency that can harm health by introducing mold, which can worsen respiratory conditions like asthma.

name: Homes with 3 or More Maintenance Deficiencies
Homes near Structures Rated Good or Excellent
description: Building quality is a strong predictor of the number of housing maintenance deficiencies in a residence that may contribute to increased risk of acute or chronic health problems.

name: Homes Using Supplemental Heat
description: The need for supplemental heat may mean a building's main heat source doesn't work - and can indicate the presence of other health-threatening maintenance deficiencies

name: Homes with Mice or Rats in the Building
description: The presence of mice or rats in the home is often associated with poor housing maintenance. These pests can contaminate food and contribute to the development and exacerbation of asthma and its symptoms.

name: Homes with Cockroaches
description: The saliva, feces, and shedding body parts of cockroaches are an allergen and can trigger asthma.

name: Adults Reporting Mold in the Home
description: Mold can worsen respiratory conditions like asthma, and indicate maintenance deficiencies in a building.

name: Renter-occupied homes with no maintenance deficiencies (TCNY2020)
Households reporting air conditioning
description: Air conditioning is an important way to avoid heat stress, especially for persons with limited mobility.

name: Homes with Grab Bars in Bathroom (among older adult households)
Court Ordered Evictions
description:
People who are threatened with eviction, even before they lose their home, are more likely to report poor health, high blood pressure, depression, anxiety, and psychological distress. Eviction often leads to residential instability, moving into poor quality housing, overcrowding, and homelessness, all of which is associated with negative health among adults and children.

(From "The Hidden Health Crisis of Eviction" by Allison Bovell-Ammo and Megan Sandel)

description: Housing without health-threatening maintenance deficiencies is an important environmental component of health.

description: Carbon monoxide detectors are required in NYC homes by law. Failure to provide or maintain a detector can put residents at risk for carbon monoxide poisoning and death.

description: Regular exercise is a key way to stay healthy.

Heat Stress Emergency Department Visits
description: ED visits due to heat stress represent part of the public health burden of extreme heat.

name: Heat Stress Hospitalizations
description: Hospitalizations due to heat stress represent part of the public health burden of extreme heat.

name: Heat Vulnerability Index
description: The New York City (NYC) Heat Vulnerability Index (HVI) is a measure of how the risk of heat-related illness or death differs across neighborhoods. Neighborhood risk factors that increase heat- vulnerability in NYC are: less home air conditioning, less green space, hotter surface temperatures, and more residents who are low-income or non-Latinx Black. Differences in these risk factors across neighborhoods are rooted in past and present racism.

name: 5-Year Heat Stress Hospitalizations
description: 5-Year Heat Stress Hospitalizations

name: Heat Vulnerability Index by NTA
description: The New York City (NYC) Heat Vulnerability Index (HVI) is a measure of how the risk of heat-related illness or death differs across neighborhoods. Neighborhood risk factors that increase heat- vulnerability in NYC are: less home air conditioning, less green space, hotter surface temperatures, and more residents who are low-income or non-Latinx Black. Differences in these risk factors across neighborhoods are rooted in past and present racism.

name: Bicycle Injury Emergency Department Visits
description: Bicycle injury ED visits can indicate the overall safety of cycling in the city - for transporation or other purposes.

description: Estimating deaths that can be linked to PM2.5 is a way to understand how air pollution increases mortality.

name: PM2.5-Attributable Asthma Emergency Department Visits
description: PM2.5-attributable asthma ED visits represent part of the health burden imposed by fine particle air pollution.

name: PM2.5-Attributable Respiratory Hospitalizations (Adults 20 Yrs and Older)
description: Estimating hospitalizations that can be linked to PM2.5 is a way to understand how air pollution impacts public health.

name: PM2.5-Attributable Cardiovascular Hospitalizations (Adults 40 Yrs and Older)
description: PM2.5-attributable cardiovascular hospitalizations represent part of the health burden imposed by fine particle air pollution.

name: O3-Attributable Cardiac and Respiratory Deaths
description: Estimating heart and respiratory deaths that can be linked to ozone is a way to understand how air pollution increases mortality.

name: O3-Attributable Asthma Emergency Department Visits
description: Ozone-attributable asthma ED visits represent part of the health burden of ozone air pollution.

name: O3-Attributable Asthma Hospitalizations
description: Ozone-attributable asthma hospitalizations represent part of the health burden of ozone air pollution.

name: Walkability Index (Infrastructure)
description:
Walkability indices summarize built environment features believed to promote walking, focusing on neighborhood infrastructure. Some potentially important characteristics are usually not included, such as neighborhood safety or attractiveness, like number of street trees.

For this index, higher scores indicate greater walkability. NYC neighborhoods range in walkability index (infrastructure) score from -4.0 to 9.4, with zero representing an approximate average for the City as a whole.

name: Vegetative Cover
description: Vegetative cover is the land covered by trees, grass, or other plants. This area is not covered by a hard surface such as paved roads, sidewalks, or buildings. Vegetative cover tends to reduce temperatures in the immediate area.

name: Tree Canopy Cover
description: The number of trees and the area shaded by them influences many neighborhood factors, such as attractiveness and lower summer temperatures that, in turn, encourage residents and visitors to walk and do other physical activity. “Tree canopy cover” measures the percent of a neighborhood that is covered (or shaded) by trees.

name: Subway Station Density
description: Many New Yorkers rely on the subway as their primary mode of transportation. Neighborhoods with greater subway access tend to have more foot traffic, making surrounding real estate highly desirable for residents and business. Subway use encourages active transportation (walking, biking), which improves the health of residents.

name: Sidewalk Area
description: Sidewalks are a critical component of New York City residents’ commute. Ample sidewalks in neighborhoods are important for commuting, businesses, and physical activity. Greater sidewalk area facilitates safer pedestrian traffic that, in turn, attracts businesses and fosters community. “Sidewalk area” measures the percent of a neighborhood that is covered by sidewalk area.

name: Walking Distance to a Park
description: Walking distance to a park is defined as 1/4-mile or less to entrances of smaller sites, such as sitting areas and playgrounds, and 1/2-mile or less to entrances of larger parks. Parks and open space that are not under the NYC Parks Department jurisdiction are also included.

name: Bicycle Network Coverage
description: The percent of streets with bike lanes can affect cyclist and pedestrian safety, physical activity, and sustainable transportation use.

name: Walking Distance to a Subway Station
description: Percentage of population within a quarter-mile of a subway station entrance.

name: Adults Reporting Air Conditioning in the Home
Daytime Summer Surface Temperature
description: Surface temperatures in NYC may vary as a function of vegetative land cover, which promotes cooling, or cover by paved roads, sidewalks, and buildings, which retain heat.

name: Vegetative Cover
description: Vegetative cover is the land covered by trees, grass, or other plants. This area is not covered by a hard surface such as paved roads, sidewalks, or buildings. Vegetative cover tends to reduce temperatures in the immediate area.

name: Adults 65+ Reporting Air Conditioning in the Home
description: Adults over the age of 65 are more vulnerable to hot weather and heat stress. Air conditioning (AC) can substantially reduce the risk of heat stroke and other heat-related illness.

name: Households reporting air conditioning
description: Air conditioning is an important way to avoid heat stress, especially for persons with limited mobility.

name: Heat Vulnerability Index
description: The New York City (NYC) Heat Vulnerability Index (HVI) is a measure of how the risk of heat-related illness or death differs across neighborhoods. Neighborhood risk factors that increase heat- vulnerability in NYC are: less home air conditioning, less green space, hotter surface temperatures, and more residents who are low-income or non-Latinx Black. Differences in these risk factors across neighborhoods are rooted in past and present racism.

name: Households reporting someone who uses electric medical equipment

Neighborhood risk factors that increase heat- vulnerability in NYC are: less home air conditioning, less green space, hotter surface temperatures, and more residents who are low-income or non-Latinx Black. Differences in these risk factors across neighborhoods are rooted in past and present racism.

Crowding (> 1 person/room)
description: Occupied housing units with more than one person per room are considered crowded.

name: Poverty
description: Neighborhood poverty is a major determinant of health, since poverty deprives people of access to health and safety resources.

name: Perception of Neighborhood Safety
description: Whether people perceive their neighborhood as safe can affect whether they will spend time outside, use parks, and use active and sustainable forms of transportation. It can also affect mental well-being.

name: Adults with Independent Living Difficulty
description:
People with disabilities or access or functional needs may need additional support during extreme weather to avoid injury, illness or even death. For example, planning needs to be made for safe travel out of evacuation zones during a hurricane, or to ensure back-up electricity is available to to support medical equipment during power outages caused by heat waves.

 

Information provided here about adults with independent living difficulties can help emergency management professionals better prepare our residents for emergencies. For more information, please visit:

NYC Emergency Management: Disabilities, Access & Functional Needs

name: Older Adults Living Alone
description: Adults over the age of 65 are more vulnerable to extreme hot and cold weather. Those that live alone may have more difficulty getting the resources they need in extreme weather events and are at higher risk of weather-related illnesses like heat stroke and hypothermia.

name: Children under 5 years old in Poverty
description: Poverty is a major determinant of health, since poverty deprives people of access to health and safety resources.

name: Jail Incarceration
description:
Each component of the criminal justice continuum - from arrest to re-entry - carries various health consequences, and a growing body of literature has documented severe adverse health outcomes associated with incarceration on the individual, their families, and neighbourhoods. 

("Structural Racism and Health Inequities in the USA: Evidence and Interventions”, by Zinzi D Bailey, ScD; Professor Nancy Krieger, PhD; Madina Agénor, ScD; Jasmine Graves, MPH; Natalia Linos, ScD; and Dr. Mary T. Bassett, MD)

name: Court Ordered Evictions
description:
People who are threatened with eviction, even before they lose their home, are more likely to report poor health, high blood pressure, depression, anxiety, and psychological distress. Eviction often leads to residential instability, moving into poor quality housing, overcrowding, and homelessness, all of which is associated with negative health among adults and children.

(From "The Hidden Health Crisis of Eviction" by Allison Bovell-Ammo and Megan Sandel)

name: Overweight or Obese Adults
description: People who are overweight or obese are at increased risk for heart disease and diabetes.

name: Obese Adults
description: People who are obese are at increased risk for heart disease and diabetes. Neighborhood factors such as walkability and the types of food retail outlets available can impact residents' risk of being overweight or obese.

name: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled
description: Traffic density is a measure of  the average number of vehicles that occupy specified area. Traffic density can influence health as a source of air pollution and traffic-related injuries.

name: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Cars
description: Traffic density is a measure of  the average number of vehicles that occupy specified area. Traffic density can influence health as a source of air pollution and traffic-related injuries.

name: Traffic Density- Annual Vehicle Miles Traveled for Trucks
description: Traffic density is a measure of  the average number of vehicles that occupy specified area. Traffic density can influence health as a source of air pollution and traffic-related injuries.

name: Adults Reporting Driving in the Last 30 Days
Hospitalizations for Asbestosis
description:
Asbestos is a naturally-occurring mineral which was commonly used as an insulation material until the 1970s. Inhaling high concentrations of asbestos fibers over a long time can produce lung inflammation and scarring resulting in the chronic lung disease called asbestosis, a type of pneumoconiosis. New York City construction, insulation, and shipyard workers who installed, disturbed, or removed asbestos without respiratory protection are at risk. Additionally, smokers who are exposed to asbestos have a greater risk of developing asbestos-related diseases than non-smokers.  

 

Typically it takes more than ten years from the time of exposure before symptoms develop. The use of proper protective masks is key to preventing the disease, since there is no treatment for this condition.

name: Elevated Blood Lead Levels among Persons Aged 16 or Older
description: In New York City, the most common cause of lead poisoning in non-pregnant adults is from occupational exposure in the construction industry. Workers are exposed by breathing in or ingesting lead dust or fumes during renovations, repairs and demolitions that disturb old, lead based paint. Workers in other industries, as well as hobbyists, may be at risk if they work with lead-containing metal, paint, pigments, ceramic glazes or bullets. Adults can also be exposed to lead through the use of lead-contaminated products, such as certain imported health remedies or medicines, spices, foods, pottery and cosmetics.

name: Hospitalizations for Pneumoconiosis
description: Pneumoconiosis is a general term given to any lung disease caused by breathing in certain particles or fibers over a prolonged period. Pneumoconiosis usually results from a workplace exposure  The most common causes of pneumoconiosis include asbestos fibers (asbestosis), silica dust (silicosis), and coal dust (coal workers’ pneumoconiosis or “Black Lung Disease”). There is no cure, but it can be prevented with appropriate respiratory protection.

name: Hospitalizations Billed to Workers’ Compensation
description: Workers’ compensation is a type of insurance that provides medical care for workers who are injured or become ill as a direct result of their job. Hospitalizations billed to workers' compensation represent only a portion of work-related injuries that require hospital care. It is important to realize that workers’ compensation policies vary from state-to-state with respect to the types of workers covered and the types of injuries and illnesses eligible for compensation.

name: Work-Related Deaths across All Industries
description:
Fatal work-related injuries include deaths resulting from unintentional injuries such as falls, acute poisonings, and motor vehicle crashes that occur during travel for work, and intentional injuries (i.e., homicides and suicides) that occur at work. Fatal injuries that occur during a person’s commute to or from work are not included.

 

Data on work-related deaths are compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries (CFOI). CFOI produces statistics on fatal work-related injuries by cross-referencing multiple sources, such as death certificates, workers' compensation reports, and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) investigation reports.

name: Work-Related Deaths in the Construction Industry Citywide
description: The New York City workforce is a diverse one and workplace risks are not distributed equally. Construction is the most dangerous industry in NYC, accounting for nearly a third of work-related injury deaths each year. Falls from scaffolds, ladders and roofs are the most common cause of fatal injuries among construction workers.

name: Work-Related Deaths in the Construction Industry by Borough
description: The New York City workforce is a diverse one and workplace risks are not distributed equally. Construction is the most dangerous industry in NYC, accounting for nearly a third of work-related injury deaths each year.

name: Babesiosis
description:
Babesiosis is a rare, sometimes severe or fatal tick-borne disease caused by Babesia microti, a protozoan parasite that infects red blood cells. Babesiosis is transmitted by the bite of an infected blacklegged tick, Ixodes scapularis, the same tick that transmits Lyme disease and anaplasmosis.  Most patients acquire this disease while traveling to endemic areas outside NYC. However, there has been an increase in the number of cases with no history of travel to endemic areas, primarily in Staten Island, as well as isolated cases in the Bronx and Queens. Babesiosis can also be transmitted through transfused blood products.

 

For more information   

NYC DOHMH Babesiosis Page

NYC DOHMH Zoonotic and Vector-borne Diseases 

CDC Babesiosis 

National Surveillance Babesiosis Case Definition

name: West Nile virus
description: West Nile virus (WNV) is an arbovirus which is transmitted through the bite of infected mosquitoes; in NYC, the mosquitoes that transmit WNV are primarily Culex pipiens as well as Culex restuans and Culex salinarius. While most people who are infected will not go on to develop symptoms, about 20% can experience mild or moderate illness and more rarely, neuroinvasive disease which can present as encephalitis or meningitis.  Most of the West Nile disease cases detected by the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene represent neuroinvasive disease as these patients are more likely to seek care.   More specific West Nile viral disease data is available on the Health Department website.

description: Monthly bicycle use is an indicator of physical activity and regular cycling.

Adults with Health Insurance
description: Health insurance coverage is associated with numerous beneficial health effects. Those with health insurance are more likely to have a regular doctor, receive preventive care services, better manage chronic health conditions, have longer life expectancy, and more.

name: Households that postponed health care in the last 12 months
Fine Particulate Matter (PM2.5)
description: Fine particles are emitted by vehicles, building boilers, and other combustion - and are a major form of air pollution that harms health.

name: Black Carbon
description: Black carbon is a major component of fine particulate matter (PM) in the air. Particulate matter is easily inhaled into the lungs and can contribute to both short-term acute health effects, as well as long-term chronic illness.

name: Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2)
description: Nitrogen oxides (NOx), which include nitric oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), are a group of pollutants formed by combusion that can cause damage to lung tissue, breathing and respiratory problems, as well as contribute to smog and acid rain.

name: Sulfur Dioxide (SO2)
description: Sulfur dioxide comes from burning certain types of fuel oil. As an air pollutant, it can can worsen lung diseases.

name: Ozone (O3)
description: Ozone is a common air pollutant that can harm breathing and worsen asthma and other respiratory conditions.

name: Nitric Oxide (NO)
description: Nitrogen oxides (NOx), which include nitric oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), are a group of pollutants formed by combusion that can cause damage to lung tissue, breathing and respiratory problems, as well as contribute to smog and acid rain.

name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease Emergency Department Visits
Non-fatal Assault Hospitalizations
description: Violence is frequently described through homicide statistics. While it is a leading cause of death and captures the most severe form of violence, non-fatal violence-related injuries resulting in hospitalizations are much more common and help paint the larger picture on the burden of violence and its impact on the health and future of individuals, families, and communities.

name: Non-fatal Assault Emergency Department Visits
description: Violence is frequently described through homicide statistics. While it is a leading cause of death and captures the most severe form of violence, non-fatal violence-related injuries resulting in emergency department visits are much more common and help paint the larger picture on the burden of violence and its impact on the health and future of individuals, families, and communities.

name: Premature Mortality
description: The rate of people who die before age 65 can indicate the overall health of a population.

name: Adult Consumption of 1 or More Sugary Drinks Per Day
Youth Consumption of 1 or More Sugary Drinks Per Day
